posts.post_content: yes this card is cool, and holy crap that harvest Wurm becomes a great friend of rogue elephant, only i wish the wurm had trample. other wise rogue elephant is still a great beat down deck card and who cares if u loose a land, take a starting hand of 2 lands, then play scent of ivy on your elephant to do 8 damage turn 2, then follow up with what other dirt cheap tricks you have.

posts.post_content:
That's a really big 1-drop. Big enough to eat [Isamaru](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Isamaru) for breakfast.
  
   
[Harvest Wurm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Harvest Wurm) is good, but it doesn't solve the problem that you're down a land. It's too bad you must sacrifice a forest, elsewise [Flagstones of Trokair](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Flagstones of Trokair) would have been a good candidate.
posts.html:
That's a really big 1-drop. Big enough to eat Isamaru for breakfast.

Harvest Wurm is good, but it doesn't solve the problem that you're down a land. It's too bad you must sacrifice a forest, elsewise Flagstones of Trokair would have been a good candidate.

Posted By: ClockworkSwordfish (2/25/2010 2:39:41 PM)

posts.post_content:
I ran a search for an answer to the flavor text. The first answer I found was "When an elephant goes rogue."  
  
Going by where I found it, it seemed to be framed in a political context. I guess a Rogue Elephant is a "maverick" Republican? Can you interpret destroying a forest as commentary on resistance to conservation efforts? Does the grass have anything to do with grassroots movements?  
  
It's fun to read way too much into things.  
  
Anyway, my answer would be "When it gets mowed down."
posts.html:
I ran a search for an answer to the flavor text. The first answer I found was "When an elephant goes rogue."

Going by where I found it, it seemed to be framed in a political context. I guess a Rogue Elephant is a "maverick" Republican? Can you interpret destroying a forest as commentary on resistance to conservation efforts? Does the grass have anything to do with grassroots movements?

It's fun to read way too much into things.

Anyway, my answer would be "When it gets mowed down."

Posted By: clyspe (9/3/2012 1:22:07 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: As a pauper player, I view this card as a death trap. Pauper is filled with high-quality, cheap removal. Getting this bolted or snuffed turn 1 is equivalent to getting LD'd and edicted(?) by a single card. For an aggro build, curving those first 3 turns is very important for tempo.
posts.html:
As a pauper player, I view this card as a death trap. Pauper is filled with high-quality, cheap removal. Getting this bolted or snuffed turn 1 is equivalent to getting LD'd and edicted(?) by a single card. For an aggro build, curving those first 3 turns is very important for tempo.

Posted By: dlgn (5/5/2012 8:37:32 PM)

posts.post_content: Unless you're planning on targetting this guy with stuff to beef it up, or attaching equipments/auras to it, consider [Scythe Tiger](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Scythe Tiger) from Zendikar, since it has *shroud* and thus is less susceptible to removal. Also, Scythe Tiger requires you to sacrifice any land, and thus is a little more flexible in decks that aren't just {G}.
posts.html:
Unless you're planning on targetting this guy with stuff to beef it up, or attaching equipments/auras to it, consider Scythe Tiger from Zendikar, since it has shroud and thus is less susceptible to removal. Also, Scythe Tiger requires you to sacrifice any land, and thus is a little more flexible in decks that aren't just {G}.

Posted By: tcollins (5/2/2012 10:54:40 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I always thought it would be great to cast this on turn one and proceed with the beatdown, but I'm not so sure anymore. You might want to cast a mana dork on turn one, followed on turn two by a land, [Rogue Elephant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rogue Elephant), *and* [Harvest Wurm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Harvest Wurm). Then a turn three [Fallow Wurm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fallow Wurm) or [Plant Elemental](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plant Elemental), depending on how many lands you have in hand.  
  
Then [Life from the Loam](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Life from the Loam) or [Crucible of Worlds](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Crucible of Worlds).
posts.html:
I always thought it would be great to cast this on turn one and proceed with the beatdown, but I'm not so sure anymore. You might want to cast a mana dork on turn one, followed on turn two by a land, Rogue Elephant, and Harvest Wurm. Then a turn three Fallow Wurm or Plant Elemental, depending on how many lands you have in hand.

Then Life from the Loam or Crucible of Worlds.
